channel.title: AutoGen on Engineering Notes
channel.description: Recent content in AutoGen on Engineering Notes

item.title: Building a Multi-Agent Code Review System with AutoGen
item.description:
Code review is a perfect use case for multi-agent systems. Different aspects of code quality—security, style, logic, performance—require different expertise. Instead of one generalist reviewer, we can create a team of specialists.

In this article, we’ll build a code review system using Microsoft’s AutoGen framework. Our team will have three specialized reviewers plus a coordinator that synthesizes their findings.

The Architecture

graph TD
    A[Code Input] --> B[Coordinator]
    B --> C[Security Reviewer]
    B --> D[Style Reviewer]
    B --> E[Logic Reviewer]
    C --> F[Final Report]
    D --> F
    E --> F

Each reviewer focuses on their domain:

item.title: Programming Multi-Agent Conversations with AutoGen
item.description:
1. Concept Introduction

At its core, AutoGen is a framework for simplifying the orchestration, optimization, and automation of complex LLM workflows. But what makes it unique is its central metaphor: conversable agents.

Simple Explanation: Imagine a team of experts in a chat room. You, the user, can talk to a project manager. This manager doesn’t do the work itself but knows which expert to talk to—a coder, a data analyst, a writer. The experts can talk to each other, execute code, ask for feedback, and report back. AutoGen allows you to program this “chat room” of AI agents.
